unnormalised: The rumble of the Mumbai local might be my usual soundtrack, but lately, a different rhythm's been pulsing through my veins: the beat of urban gym culture. It's more than just lifting weights; it's a whole vibe, a lifestyle, especially in cities like Delhi and Bangalore. Remember that toned physique Hrithik Roshan flaunted in "Dhoom 2"? Well, that's the aspiration fuel.

unnormalised: I first dipped my toe in at a local Gold's Gym near my college, Hindu College, Delhi. It was intimidating initially – so many chiseled bodies grunting through reps. But the energy was infectious. Soon, I was hooked, trading chai breaks for protein shakes.

unnormalised: It's not just about vanity, though. It's a stress reliever. After a long day battling traffic and deadlines at work, hitting the gym feels like hitting a reset button. The endorphins kick in, and suddenly, that looming deadline feels a little less daunting.

unnormalised: The rise of boutique fitness studios also adds to the flavour. From CrossFit boxes teaching you to snatch and clean to Zumba studios blasting Bollywood remixes, there’s something for everyone. My friend Priya swears by her Pilates class in Bandra, says it's the only thing keeping her sane amidst the madness.

unnormalised: And the community aspect is huge. You meet people from all walks of life, all sweating towards a common goal. We compare workout routines, exchange protein recipes (paneer tikka masala is a surprisingly good source!), and motivate each other on tough days. It’s a shared struggle, a shared victory, every rep at a time. My trainer, Ramesh, always says, "Every day is a chance to become a better you". He’s right. Even on days when I feel like I can barely lift 5 kg, I show up. Because that’s what urban gym culture is about: consistency, community, and a whole lot of sweat. Plus, who wouldn’t want to look a little more like Hrithik? Maybe one day I'll be able to run 10 km without feeling like dying!
